Highly active CoP-Co2N confined in nanocarbon enabling efficient electrocatalytic immobilizing-conversion of polysulfide targeting high-rate lithium-sulfur batteries Xiaojun Zhao a ⁎ Tianqi Gao b Wenhao Ren c Chuan Zhao c ⁎ Zhi-Hong Liu b Linbo Li a a School of Metallurgical Engineering, Xi'an University of Architecture and Technology, Xi'an 710055, Shaanxi, China School of Metallurgical Engineering Xi'an University of Architecture and Technology Xi'an 710055 Shaanxi China School of Metallurgical Engineering, Xi'an University of Architecture and Technology, Xi'an 710055, Shaanxi, China b School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Shaanxi Normal University, Xi’an 710062, Shaanxi, China School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Shaanxi Normal University Xi’an 710062 Shaanxi China School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Shaanxi Normal University, Xi’an 710062, Shaanxi, China c School of Chemistry, University of New South Wales, Sydney, NSW 2052, Australia School of Chemistry University of New South Wales Australia School of Chemistry, University of New South Wales, Australia ⁎ Corresponding authors. Graphical abstract The CoP-Co2N@NC/CG with abundant electrocatalytic-adsorption sites as a sulfur reservoir is constructed to improve the electrochemical performances of Li-S batteries. Lithium-sulfur batteries suffer from poor cycling stability because of the intrinsic shuttling effect of intermediate polysulfides and sluggish reaction kinetics, especially at high rates and high sulfur loading. Herein, we report the construction of a CoP-Co2N@N-doped carbon polyhedron uniformly anchored on three-dimensional carbon nanotubes/graphene (CoP-Co2N@NC/CG) scaffold as a sulfur reservoir to achieve the trapping-diffusion-conversion of polysulfides. Highly active CoP-Co2N shows marvelous catalytic effects by effectively accelerating the reduction of sulfur and the oxidation of Li2S during the discharging and charging process, respectively, while the conductive NC/CG network with massive mesoporous channels ensures fast and continuous long-distance electron/ion transportation. DFT calculations demonstrate that the CoP-Co2N with excellent intrinsic conductivity serves as job-synergistic immobilizing-conversion sites for polysulfides through the formation of P···Li/N···Li and Co···S bonds. As a result, the S@CoP-Co2N@NC/CG cathode (sulfur content 1.7 mg cm−2) exhibits a high capacity of 988 mAh g−1 at 2 C after 500 cycles, which is superior to most of the electrochemical performance reported. Even under high sulfur content (4.3 mg cm−2), it also shows excellent cyclability with high capacity at 1 C. Keywords CoP-Co2N@NC/CG Trapping-diffusion-conversion High-rate DFT calculation Li-S battery 1 Introduction Lithium-sulfur (Li-S) batteries are recognized as one of the most promising energy storage systems with a high theoretical capacity of 1675 mAh g−1 based on all the reaction products are all the reaction products being Li2S (S8 + 16e- + 16Li+ = 8Li2S), along with the low-cost and environmental benignity of sulfur [1–4]. Unfortunately, the practical application of Li-S batteries is seriously hindered by the physicochemical problems at the sulfur cathode, namely, the insulating nature of sulfur and solid-state discharge products (Li2S/Li2S2), and the shuttling effect of high-order lithium polysulfide intermediates (LPSs, Li2S n , 4 ≤ n ≤ 8) in the liquid electrolyte [5–7]. To circumvent these hurdles, tremendous efforts have been devoted to designing various host materials to accommodate the active guest materials reliably and efficiently, such as carbon-based materials [8,9], conductive polymers [10,11], polar inorganic materials [12–14], Among these attempts, the encapsulation of sulfur into porous carbon/polar inorganic materials is a straightforward strategy. By physically mixing or chemically assembling, these porous carbons as sulfur hosts can offer appreciable conductivity and large internal space to accommodate the volume fluctuation of active sulfur during cycling, and prevent the diffusion and side reactions of sulfur [15–17]. Carbon nanotubes (CNTs) and graphene (G) nanosheets are promising candidates due to their good conductivity, high specific surface area, excellent mechanical strength, and flexibility [18]. Unfortunately, the re-aggregation of CNTs and G during the material synthesis leads to limited performance improvement. Therefore, the synthesis of an efficient multifunctional 3D CNTs/G support is important, which requires innovative material designs. Even so, once oxidized or reduced to soluble LPSs, the detachment of sulfur species from the carbon support could occur because of the rather weak affinity between the nonpolar carbon and polar LPSs, resulting in the high-impedance and sluggish redox kinetics. Recent advances have been made on polar hosts, such as transition metal oxides [19,20], sulfides/selenide [21–23], phosphide [24,25], nitrides [26,27], and boride [28,29]. The conversion of LPSs to Li2S2/Li2S with the aid of these polar inorganic materials is promising to suppress the shuttling effect, and improve the capacity retention and cycling stability at low and medium rates due to their outstanding anchoring behaviour, whereas the performances at high rates are still unsatisfied owing to the poor electrical conductivity and slow redox conversion of sulfur species. Meanwhile, the adsorbed LPSs must be easily reduced and oxidized during discharging and charging process, otherwise, these adsorbed LPSs ultimately become “dead weight” and “dead volume” sulfur (no contribution to the reversible capacity) [30]. In light of this, integrating polar compounds with conductive polar nanocrystals or carbon materials is a feasible approach to synergize the anchoring behaviour and conversion capabilities of LPSs, and achieve a prolonged cycling life and excellent rate performance. Among these options, metal phosphide and nitrides possess higher conductivities and catalytic activities for LPSs than the corresponding metal oxides. Song et al. [31] designed a VO2-VN binary host for advanced Li-S batteries with a high sulfur content, in which VO2 exhibits the advantages of highly adsorptive VO2 and attractively conductive VN. Qian et al. [32] reported an rGO/CoP composite for Li-S batteries, which shows better conductivity of cathode and suppresses shuttling effects compared to rGO/Co3O4 and rGO/Co4N. This contribution shows a highly active CoP-Co2N@N doped C/CNTs/G (CoP-Co2N@NC/CG) sulfur host derived from ZIF-67 grafted on a 3D hierarchical carbon nanotubes/graphene oxide (denoted as ZIF-67/CNTs/GO) via facile and one-step self-assembly. Highly active CoP-Co2N provides strong chemical adsorption and effective catalytic activity, which is confirmed by a range of experiments and density functional theory (DFT) calculations. The NC nanocage can physically confines the diffusion of LPSs molecules acts as a secondary barrier and offers efficient pathways for fast Li+/e- transport. Besides, the CG network servers as the matrix to support CoP-Co2N@NC to prevent mechanical peeling-off and constructs a long-range conductive network during the cycling. By virtue of these superior priorities, the S@CoP-Co2N@NC/CG cathode shows significantly enhanced electrochemical performances in terms of specific capacity, rate capability, and cycling stability. 2 Results and discussion 2.1 Morphology and structure characterization The synthesis procedure of the CoP-Co2N@NC/CG host is schematically depicted in Fig. 1 (a) (see the Experimental Section for details): i) GO and acid-functionalized CNTs were mixed and dispersed in methanol by ultrasonic, in which both GO and CNTs with the electronegative oxygen functional groups serve as nucleation centres for ZIF-67, thus in-situ self-assembly of ZIF-67/CNTs/GO (Fig. S1a and b); ii) Thermal conversion process was applied to transform ZIF-67/CNTs/GO to Co@NC/CG, in which the ZIF-67 are first converted to Co@NC as the self-sacrificing template while GO is reduced to G; iii) To obtain the highly active CoP-Co2N@NC/CG host, the Co@NC/CG was first partially nitridated, and then phosphatized by dicyandiamide and NaH2PO2·H2O, respectively. In CoP-Co2N@NC/CG, both G and CNTs carbon materials play the same role in synergistically improving the conductivity of electrode materials during electrochemical reactions. However, the role of the two in the synthesis of the CoP-Co2N@NC/CG scaffold and how each exerts its electrical conductivity are different. In the synthesis of the CoP-Co2N@NC/CG scaffold, the role of CNTs is to connect individual CoP-Co2N@NC in series, which not only facilitates the construction of a structurally stable S@CoP-Co2N@NC/CG cathode, but also facilitates electron transfer between the cathodes of each unit. Nevertheless, the length of the CNTs is limited, and the scattered CoP-Co2N@NC cannot be effectively connected in series. Therefore, the introduction of G can initially fix CoP-Co2N@NC on both sides of G to form a foam-like 3D structure, then connect CoP-Co2N@NC in series through CNTs, and finally form a stable 3D network and multi-path conductive electrode material. During the charge–discharge process, the G-supported S@CoP-Co2N@NC with good flexibility can enable synchronous deformation along with a volume change of S@CoP-Co2N@NC, thus effectively preventing the degradation of the mechanical integrity. The surface morphology of the as-prepared samples was firstly characterized by field-emission scanning electron microscopy (SEM). In Fig. S1(b), the self-assembled ZIF-67/CNTs/GO precursor shows 3D morphology, in which these dodecahedrons ZIF-67 are deposited on the 3D structure assembled by GO and CNTs. After annealing of precursors, Co@NC/CG, Co-Co2N@NC/CG, and CoP@NC/CG present the 3D hierarchical morphology similar to ZIF-67/CNTs/GO, but with a rough concave dodecahedral and additional CNTs with a smaller diameter catalyzed by metallic Co nanoparticles during the pyrolysis treatment process of ZIF-67 (Fig. S2 a-c) [33,34]. CG presents a conductive and robust 3D framework with G nanosheets tightly crosslinked with CNTs (Fig. S2d). In Fig. 1(b), the CoP-Co2N@NC/CG largely inherits a hierarchical interpenetration morphology structure of Co-Co2N@NC/CG and CoP@NC/CG samples of a uniform arrangement of CoP-Co2N@NC-assembled CNTs and G, and the size of the CoP-Co2N@NC in CoP-Co2N@NC/CG is ∼250 nm. Moreover, the CoP-Co2N@NC/CG with a large surface area is unique and 3D, which is conducive for ions and e- transmission throughout the entire composite, and dramatically increases the electrochemical properties. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) of CoP-Co2N@NC/CG (Fig. 1c) further demonstrates that numerous CoP-Co2N nanoparticles are encapsulated closely and homogenously inside the NC nanocage. In addition, some CoP-Co2N nanoparticles and generated CNTs are also distributed on the surface of graphene. High-resolution TEM (HRTEM) image of CoP-Co2N@NC/CG (Fig. 1d) reveals fringe spacings of about 0.28 and 0.25 nm referring to the (011) and (111) crystal facets of CoP, [35,36] respectively. The interlayer spaces of 0.24 and 0.20 nm correspond to the (110) and (021) lattice planes of Co2N [37], respectively. We noted that the heterogeneous interface of CoP and Co2N in CoP-Co2N@NC/CG is widespread and can be easily observed. After S loading, the high-angle annular dark-field scanning TEM (HAADF-STEM) and elemental mapping images of S@CoP-Co2N@NC/CG (Fig. 1e) also confirm that C, N, Co, P, and S are homogeneously distributed over the whole nanostructure. It is observed that the distribution area of the S element is slightly smaller than other elements, suggesting that S has been well-confined inside the nanocages. The powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns indicate that the CoP-Co2N@NC/CG and S@CoP-Co2N@NC/CG have been successfully synthesized (Fig. 2a). The CoP-Co2N@NC/CG displays characteristics (011), (200), (112), (103), and (301) peaks, corresponding to the CoP phase (JCPDS No. 29–0497), and (110), (111), (021), and (130) peaks of the Co2N phase with orthorhombic (JCPDS No. 06–0647). As for S@CoP-Co2N@NC/CG, a series of diffraction peaks match well with the Fddd orthorhombic structure of S8 (JCPDS No. 08–0247), CoP, and Co2N phases, respectively, indicating the incorporation of S into the CoP-Co2N@NC/CG host. The diffraction peaks of control samples, such as the CoP@NC/CG and Co-Co2N@NC/CG composites are well assigned to CoP, and Co-Co2N (Fig. S3), respectively. The thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) in air demonstrates that the carbon component (NC/CG) in CoP-Co2N@NC/CG composite is ∼47.3 wt%, and the content of CoP and Co2N is calculated as 31.0 and 20.6 wt% (Fig. S4), respectively. Moreover, the S content in S@CoP-Co2N@NC/CG composite is determined by TGA in nitrogen (Fig. 2b). A mass loss of about 4.8% is observed in the TG curve below 138 °C, and an endothermic process around 120 °C in the DSC curve can be assigned to the loss of physically adsorbed water. From the beginning of 155.5 °C to the appearance of a strong endothermic peak at 292.3 °C, the severe mass loss of about 73.3% is attributed to the loss of S. Fig. S5 shows the Raman spectrum of CG, CoP-Co2N@NC/CG, and S@CoP-Co2N@NC/CG, which displays two characteristic peaks at around 1342.5 and 1578.3 cm−1, respectively, originated from the disordered/defective carbon (D-band, sp 3) and ordered/graphitic carbon (G-band, sp 2).[36,38] The intensity ratio of I D/I G of CoP-Co2N@NC/CG (1.1) and S@ CoP-Co2N@NC/CG (1.2) confirms a large number of defects and high disorder structure of NC/CG. The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) specific surface area of the CoP-Co2N@NC/CG scaffold estimated from the isotherms (Fig. 2c) is 210.8 m2 g−1, which is smaller than that of CG (350.2 m2 g−1). With the impregnation of sulfur into the CoP-Co2N@NC/CG matrix, the specific surface area of S@CoP-Co2N@NC/CG drops to 62.8 m2 g−1. The BJH porous size distribution ranges from 2.5 to 18.2 nm, whereas the pore volume S@CoP-Co2N@NC/CG shows a substantial decrease, indicating that the mesopores in the host are impregnated with sulfur. Such a hierarchical structure with a large surface area and rich mesopore offers more active sites to facilitate the adsorption and redox reactions of LPSs and alleviate the volumetric expansion during the lithiation process. 2.2 Understanding the inhibition mechanism of LPSs To evaluate the adsorptive in trapping LPSs, ex-situ adsorption measurement using ultraviolet–visible (UV–vis) was also carried out to probe the concentration changes of LPSs after adding CG, Co-Co2N@NC/CG, CoP@NC/CG, and CoP-Co2N@NC/CG hosts, taking Li2S6 in 1, 3-dioxolane/dimethoxyethane (DOL/DME, 1:1 v/v) as the LPSs representative. In Fig. S6 and Fig. 3 (a), when the same mass of each host is added to a fixed volume of Li2S6-DOL/DME solution, the yellow Li2S6 solution changes to bright yellow after the addition of CoP-Co2N@NC/CG for 40 min quiescence. After 4 h, the Li2S6 in the CoP-Co2N@NC/CG becomes nearly transparent, while the Li2S6 exhibits a faint yellow colour in Co-Co2N@NC/CG and CoP@NC/CG. Then after 10 h standing, the solutions containing Co-Co2N@NC/CG and CoP@NC/CG also become completely colorless. In contrast, the CG solution still exhibits a slight yellow colour because of the weak interaction of CG with Li2S6. The concentration change of LPSs in the solution containing the four samples is further compared by UV–vis absorption spectra from the upper solution (Fig. 3b). Apparently, the absorbance of the solutions containing Co-based@NC/CG in the visible light range decrease dramatically. The S4 2- peaks almost vanish with CoP@NC/CG and CoP-Co2N@NC/CG, and CoP-Co2N@NC/CG shows the lowest absorbance intensity for S6 2- and S4 2- peaks [39,40]. Therefore, the order of absorbance intensity of the LPSs solution is Co-Co2N@NC/CG > CoP@NC/CG > CoP-Co2N@NC/CG in the ultraviolet light region, which suggests that the CoP-Co2N@NC/CG has the most effective and strongest adsorption for the wide composition range of LPSs. The CoP-Co2N@NC/CG after static Li2S6 adsorption for 10 h was dried under vacuum for 12 h and then prepared for X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurement. The strong chemical interaction between CoP-Co2N@NC/CG and Li2S6 is determined by comparing the XPS before and after adsorping Li2S6 (Fig. 3c-f and Fig. S7). The presence of the S element can be obviously observed from the wide spectrum of LPSs-adsorbed CoP-Co2N@NC/CG, indicating a substantial adsorption amount of LPSs on the surface of CoP-Co2N@NC/CG. The Co 2p XPS spectra of CoP-Co2N@NC/CG before adsorption show three peaks at 781.8, 783.6, and 787.2 eV for Co 2p 3/2, which are assigned to stand for Co3+, Co2+, and relevant satellite peaks (Sat.), respectively (Fig. 3c) [41,42]. This Co3+ 2p and Co2+ 2p peaks after adsorption of Li2S6 shift to lower energy than that of before adsorption by 0.5 eV, indicating the partial positive charges (δ + ) of Co are transferred to more electronegative S. Before the adsorption of Li2S6, the N 1s XPS spectra of CoP-Co2N@NC/CG (Fig. 3d) show the existence of four peaks located at 402.0, 400.7, 399.8, and 398.6 eV, corresponding to graphitic N, Co-N, pyrrolic N and pyridinic N [43], respectively. Interestingly, CoP-Co2N@NC/CG has a high content of electron-accepting pyridinic N and graphitic N, which potentially generate the δ+ on adjacent sp 2-hybridized carbon, thereby enhancing the interaction with LPSs through dipole–dipole interaction [44]. For P 2p, the peak appears at 134.1 eV, corresponding to PO bonds due to the as-prepared product under exposure to air (Fig. 3e). Two peaks centred at 129.9 and 129.1 eV match with P 2p 1/2 and P 2p 3/2 in the phosphorus of Co-P. After adsorption, the binding energies of the N 1s (Co-N, pyrrolic N, and pyridinic N) and P 2p (Co-P) bonds up-shifts of 0.1 eV, which can be ascribed to the interactions between the electropositive Li atom in Li2S6 and Co-P and N active groups, respectively [45,46]. Additionally, the surface chemical properties of Li2S6-absorbed CoP-Co2N@NC/CG are further analyzed by XPS. Fig. 3(f) shows a typical S 2p spectrum of sulfonate group with one broad peak located at 167.9 eV, which is likely produced via the surface oxidation of LPSs [47,48]. Fortunately, the insoluble thiosulfate formed on the surface can act as a mediator, immobilizing the long-chain LPSs from the solution and initiating their conversion to Li2S2/Li2S [49]. Meanwhile, Li2S6 shows the two pairs of peaks corresponding to the terminal S (ST -1) at 161.9 eV and bridging S (SB 0) at 163.3 eV. As a result, the above ex-situ visual adsorption and XPS analysis demonstrate that the interaction and the synergistic effects among Co and P/N-containing active groups in the CoP-Co2N@NC/CG significantly contribute to suppressing the shuttle effect of LPSs. 2.3 Electrochemical characterization To elucidate the effects of CoP-Co2N@NC/CG on the Li-S redox kinetics, the kinetics reactions of liquid–liquid and liquid–solid were studied. The cyclic voltammetry (CV) in symmetric cell arrangements with and without 0.5 mol/L Li2S6 electrolyte within −1.0 to 1.0 V from 10 to 25 mV s−1 was measured with CoP-Co2N@NC/CG, CoP@NC/CG, Co-Co2N@NC/CG, and CG as both working and reference/counter electrodes to probe the liquid–liquid reaction. As shown in Fig. 4 (a) and Fig. S8, CV curves of the Li2S6-free symmetrical cells exhibit minor capacitive current contribution (near-zero capacitive current density), while the Li2S6 symmetrical cells show much higher redox current responses. The current response intensity and the corresponding potential of the peak currents confirm that the CoP-Co2N@NC/CG host possesses a better catalytic activity than the other hosts, which facilitates the LPSs conversion reaction. Compared to CV curves of the CoP@NC/CG and Co-Co2N@NC/CG, these redox peaks of the CoP-Co2N@NC/CG are still well maintained with only a slight shift with the increase of the scan rates (Fig. S9a-c). According to the D Li+ ∝i p/v 0.5 [18,27], the slope of the CoP-Co2N@NC/CG is bigger than those of the CoP@NC/CG and Co-Co2N@NC/CG (Fig. S9d), demonstrating the accelerated Li+ diffusion rate and enhanced conversion kinetics of Li2S6. All the above are evidence of the superior reaction dynamics of polysulfide conversion on the CoP-Co2N@NC/CG surface. Such kinetic benefit is further confirmed in the Li2S deposition behaviours, in which potentiostatic discharge profiles of the Li2S8-containing electrolyte at 2.09 V are collected (Fig. 4b-e). According to reports, the chemical nucleation of Li2S on the host surface strongly relies on the chemical environments, including charge access capability and deposit-host affinity [50,51]. As a result, the capacity of Li2S precipitation on the CoP-Co2N@NC/CG interface is calculated as 246 mAh g−1, which is evidently higher than those on CoP@NC/CG (186 mAh g−1), Co-Co2N@NC/CG (139 mAh g−1), and CG (63 mAh g−1) (based on the weight of sulfur in the catholyte), respectively. The higher capacity for the CoP-Co2N@NC/CG further confirms the accelerated conversion from the liquid Li2S8/Li2S6 to Li2S, which is driven by CoP-Co2N@NC/CG with abundant nucleation sites and charge access ability to LPSs, illustrating the superiority of highly active CoP-Co2N [52]. Galvanostatic intermittent titration technique (GITT) was applied to detect the interfacial reaction resistance at different charge/discharge stages. During the GITT measurements, a current density of 0.1 C is applied for 5 min to obtain the closed-circuit-voltage (CCV), and then resting for another 5 min to collect the potential response (quasi-open-circuit-voltage, QOCV) in the first cycle between 1.5 to 2.8 V. Comparing the GITT curves (Fig. 4f), the S@CoP-Co2N@NC/CG cathode delivers the largest specific capacities and smaller voltage hysteresis (ΔV, voltage gap between the discharge and charge plateaus) [38], which further confirms the enhanced kinetics. In addition, the S@CoP-Co2N@NC/CG displays the lowest reaction resistances during the charge and discharge process (Fig. 4g), as calculated from the difference between CCV and QOCV [53]. The above results demonstrate that CoP-Co2N@NC/CG could significantly accelerate the redox kinetics of LPSs conversions in the S@CoP-Co2N@NC/CG cathode. The design principle and characterization of the S@CoP-Co2N@NC/CG are further represented by schematic diagrams (Fig. 4h and i), including the LPSs conversion processes on the CoP-Co2N surface and the fast Li+/e- transmission channel of the CG framework. To analyze the electrochemical reaction mechanism and further emphasize the kinetic advantage of S@CoP-Co2N@NC/CG, the comparison of CV profiles of S@CoP-Co2N@NC/CG, S@CoP@NC/CG, S@Co-Co2N@NC/CG, and S@CG electrodes at 0.1 mV s−1 within 1.5 to 2.8 V is evaluated. The sulfur content in S@CoP-Co2N@NC/CG is ∼1.7 mg cm−2. In Fig. 5 (a), all the S-based cathodes show the typical multistep sulfur redox reactions. Two pronounced cathodic peaks at 2.31 and 2.03 V for S@CoP-Co2N@NC/CG cathode represent the reduction of α-S8 molecules to soluble long-chain lithium polysulfides (Li2S n , 4 ≤ n ≤ 8), and subsequent reduction to insoluble short-chain Li2S2 or Li2S, respectively [54,55]. In the reverse scan, the peak at 2.44 V corresponds to the oxidation of Li2S2/Li2S to Li2S8/β-S8 [54,56]. Notably, the two cathodic peaks and the anodic peak appear at a higher potential, which can be attributed to the accelerated redox reactions of sulfur species and the rearrangement of active materials to energetically more stable sites [6,57,58]. It is worth noting that the S@CoP-Co2N@NC/CG cathode exhibits a smaller potential gap for the redox peaks, reflecting its much-mitigated polarization and enhanced redox reaction kinetics of sulfur. However, the insufficient catalytic activity of CG (The increased peak potential positions) degrades greatly the conversion kinetics of S@CG, leading to serious compromise of the CV peak area. The galvanostatic discharge/charge tests at different C-rates (From 0.1 to 4 C) further confirm the enhanced kinetics of the S@CoP-Co2N@NC/CG within the voltage range of 1.6–2.8 V (Fig. S10), where the voltage hysteresis (ΔV) is defined as the distance between the charge voltage plateaus and negative of discharge voltage plateaus at a half capacity [38,59]. In Fig. S11, the S@CoP-Co2N@NC/CG further exhibits the smallest ΔV than those of other control electrodes, in good agreement with CV results. This demonstrates the excellent rate capability of S@CoP-Co2N@NC/CG in realizing low polarization, accelerated redox kinetics of LPSs, and enhanced electronic/ionic transport properties of the highly active CoP-Co2N and 3D conductive carbon network. In addition, it can be observed that the value of the ΔV increases with the increased C-rates, especially for the S@GC electrode. Additionally, the S@CoP-Co2N@NC/CG composite displays an excellent rate performance (Fig. 5b and c). For example, at the current densities increasing from 0.1 to 0.2, 0.5, and 1 C (1 C = 1675 mA g−1), the average specific capacity of S@CoP-Co2N@NC/CG composite per every 10 cycles is ∼1402, 1289, 1182, and 1129 mAh g−1 (determined by measuring the mass of S), respectively. Even at the high rates of 2 and 4 C, its average specific capacity can remain ∼1045 and ∼972 mAh g−1, ∼75% and ∼69% of initial specific capacity, respectively. Importantly, an average capacity of 1180 mAh g−1 is retained when the current returns back to 0.2 C, indicating a highly reversible rate performance of S@CoP-Co2N@NC/CG. The energy density of the battery is very important for the practicality of lithium-sulfur batteries, which is generally divided into gravimetric energy density (E weight) and volumetric energy density (E volumetric). At a current density of 0.1, 0.2, 0.5, 1, 2, and 4 C, the corresponding E weight value is 2972, 2720, 2470, 2325, 2090, and 1905 Wh kg−1, and the E volumetric value is 1974, 1806, 1640, 1544, 1388, and 1265 Wh cm−3 (Fig. S12), respectively. In contrast, the S@Co-Co2N@NC/CG and S@CoP@NC/CG electrodes exhibit lower average specific capacities but are still much higher than those of S@CG under identical test conditions. Clearly, S@CoP-Co2N@NC/CG displays the best rate performances, in particular at a high current density of 4 C. Compared with reported sulfur cathodes with high sulfur contents (Table S1), this S@CoP-Co2N@NC/CG cathode also presents better rate performances at 0.1 C and 4 C, which confirming an unequivocal advantage to suppress the “shuttle effect” of CoP-Co2N@NC/CG. In Fig. 5(d), the S@CoP-Co2N@NC/CG electrode further presents excellent cycling stability at 0.2 C. It can deliver a high initial discharge specific capacity of 1307 mAh g−1, and then decreases slowly to 1269 mAh g−1 after 100 cycles with excellent Coulombic efficiency (CE) over 99%, corresponding to the average capacity decay per cycle as low as 0.0291%. While the S@Co-Co2N@NC/CG, S@CoP@NC/CG, and S@CG electrodes show lower specific capacities and inferior cycling properties. After 100 cycles, the discharge capacities of their samples decrease from 1182, 1056, and 853 mAh g−1 to 1025, 876, and 548 mAh g−1, respectively. To further evaluate the long-term rate performance of the S@CoP-Co2N@NC/CG electrode, the cycling test at a high C-rate of 2 C and 4 C is conducted. After activation at a low current density of 0.1 C and 0.2 C (Fig. 5e), the S@CoP-Co2N@NC/CG then remains very stable afterward, and the capacity can still be maintained at 988 mAh g−1 after 500 cycles at 2 C with a high CE> 99%. Even at 4 C (Fig. S13), its specific capacity can remain at ∼695 mAh g−1 after 500 cycles, delivering a retention rate up to 61.6% of the first cycle. In addition, it is crucial to obtain cathodes with high areal sulfur loading and stable cycling performance to meet the real application of Li-S batteries. To pursue better practical viability, we investigate the electrochemical performances of S@CoP-Co2N@NC/CG cathode with various areal loading mass (1.7, 2.4, 3.5, and 4.3 mg cm−2). At a current density of 1 C (Fig. 5f), the specific capacities can still reach up to ∼1165, 1053, 1025, and 1015, and retain ∼1093, 950, 808, and 731 mAh g−1 (with ∼93.8, 90.2, 78.8, and 72.0% retention) after 150 cycles, respectively. Corresponding areal capacities ranging from 1.9 to 3.2 mAh cm−2 can be achieved after 150 cycles, revealing the significant potential with high mass loading of S (Fig. S14). In addition, it is also confirmed that the CoP-Co2N@NC/CG host itself does not contribute significantly to the capacity. The initial discharging specific capacity is only 157.6 mAh g−1 and less than 11 mAh g−1 after 100 cycles between 1.6 and 2.8 V (Fig. S15). Based on the above results, the S@CoP-Co2N@NC/CG displays the best electrochemical performances in terms of specific capacity, rate capability, and cycling stability, which is consistent with the results of the UV–vis analysis and kinetic study of LPSs. These results reveal that the presence of CoP-Co2N and 3D CG conductive network can effectively overcome the redox kinetic barriers of polysulfides, and enhance the Li+/e- transportation for high sulfur utilization. The electrochemical impedance spectrum (EIS) also reveals a lower charge transfer resistance (Rct) for S@CoP-Co2N@NC/CG concerning other S-based electrodes (Fig. S16a and Table S2). Furthermore, the lithium diffusion (D Li+, cm2 S− 1) value of the S@CoP-Co2N@NC/CG electrode is estimated to be 7.5 × 10− 13, which is also higher than those of the S@CoP@NC/CG (4.0 × 10− 13), S@Co-Co2N@NC/CG (2.0 × 10− 13), and S@CG (1.1 × 10− 13) electrodes in the low-frequency region (Fig. S16b). These results indicate that the coupling of the highly active CoP-Co2N and NC/CG in CoP-Co2N@NC/CG is beneficial to accelerating the mass/electron transfer and the conversion/diffusion reaction of LPSs, thereby promoting fast and stable Li-S batteries [52,60]. To investigate the influence of the cycling process on the S@CoP-Co2N@NC/CG cathode, the cycled cells were disassembled after 100 cycles. In Fig. 6 (a), it can be clearly noticed that the damaged metallic Li plate anode surface and plenty of LPSs intermediates in the separator for the S@CG can be observed, suggesting the serious side reactions on the surface of the Li electrode and poor confinement of LPSs. In contrast, for the cycled S@CoP-Co2N@NC/CG electrode, the surface of the Li anode is almost undamaged, and only a very small amount of LPSs can be observed in the separator, suggesting the effectiveness of CoP-Co2N@NC/CG for LPSs immobilization and redox promotion. Furthermore, the SEM and TEM images distinctly reveal that the microstructure of CoP-Co2N@NC/CG could be essentially preserved (Fig. 6b and c). More importantly, the heterogeneous interface of CoP and Co2N in CoP-Co2N@NC/CG still exists from the HRTEM image in Fig. 6(d). Consequently, it is reasonable that the assembled Li-S batteries employing the S@CoP-Co2N@NC/CG cathodes show excellent electrochemical reversibility and stability. 2.4 Theoretical simulation and calculation Density functional theory (DFT) calculations of the adsorption of LPSs on CoP and Co2N surfaces were performed to show the mechanism of their trapping, and the Li2S6 is chosen as the prototype for modeling. To explore the synergistic adsorption mechanism of CoP-Co2N for Li2S6, P doping on the Co2N (021) surface as its structure model is labeled as P-Co2N. Fig. 7 (a-c) respectively presents the optimized adsorption configurations of Li2S6 adsorption on CoP (011), Co2N (021), and P-Co2N (021) surfaces. As can be observed, the absorbability of CoP for Li2S6 mainly originated from the double interactions between the surface Co and P atoms from CoP, and the S and Li atoms from Li2S6 to Co-S bonds and two Li-P bonds. The Li2S6 adsorption configuration shows that an S* atom is disconnected from the original Li-S6-Li chain, and rearranged to the end of the chain, forming the additional Li-S* bond and two Co-S* bonds. It is worth noting that the rearrangement reaction of the S* atom ultimately produces five Co-S bonds. Similar behavior rearrangement reaction of the S* is observed for Co2N (021) surfaces, but the binding modes of Li2S6 on Co2N (021) surfaces are distinct from those on CoP, where N and Co atoms in Co2N form one Li-N bond and four Co-S bonds with Li2S6. It can be found that the bond lengths of Li-N (1.98 Å) and Co-S (average 2.16 Å) of Li2S6-Co2N are shorter compared to those of Li-P (2.56 Å) and Co-S (average 2.24 Å) of Li2S6-CoP, respectively. On the P-Co2N (021) surface, one Li atom in Li2S6 tends to bridge to two P atom sites, and the S atoms still bond with Co to form four Co-S bonds. After that, P-Co2N exhibits the highest adsorption energy (ΔE Li2S6) for Li2S6 (-4.59 eV), which is slightly stronger than that of CoP (-4.50 eV), whereas the Co2N shows the weakest adsorbability (-3.81 eV) (Fig. 7d). Obviously, the adsorption energy of both CoP and Co2N hosts for Li2S6 is much higher than that of metallic Co or graphene [56,61]. These results are consistent with the UV–vis analysis that CoP-Co2N efficiently prevents LPSs from dissolving. Furthermore, to study the impact of P doping on the electronic property of Co2N, the density of states (DOS) of Co2N and P-Co2N were calculated (Fig. 7e). The obvious Fermi level crossing the conduction bands of the Co2N and P-Co2N indicates their metallic characteristics [62,63]. Additionally, the DOS of both the N doping on CoP (011) surface (N-CoP) and CoP also exhibits their superior conductive nature (Fig. 7f). P-Co2N and N-CoP display an increased DOS with respect to that of Co2N and CoP, respectively, suggesting that the P-Co2N and N-CoP can provide more charge carriers to take part in the electrochemical reaction [62,64]. The above experimental and calculation results provide solid evidence of the strongest adsorption and anchoring effect of CoP-Co2N@NC/CG composite for LPSs, which explains well the different electrochemical performances of the corresponding materials in Li-S batteries. 3 Conclusions We have introduced the highly active CoP-Co2N electroactive centres with simultaneous construction of a 3D hierarchically porosity carbon network as a multifunctional sulfur reservoir for Li–S batteries. As corroborated by the experimental and theoretical results, the highly polar CoP-Co2N@NC/CG possesses a strong chemical affinity to sulfur species by the formation of Li···P, N···Li, and Co···S bonds, which effectually anchor LPSs intermediates to impede their shuttle effect. More significantly, CoP-Co2N facilitates the reduction of sulfur species and the oxidation of Li2S. The hierarchical porous 3D NC/CG framework not only severs as a physical barrier and builds a long-range conductive network for fast charge transfer, but also enables high sulfur accommodation and synergistically buffers its large volume expansion as well as offers a large number of charge and electrolyte transport channels during cycling. Attributed to these synergistic benefits of adsorption-catalysis-conversion, the S@CoP-Co2N@NC/CG cathode displays long-term cyclability with a high reversible capacity and excellent rate capability. We hope the 3D heterointerface/C network structures design may offer an effective strategy to solve the high-sulfur-loaded hosts for high-performance Li-S batteries and extend other energy storage and conversion. coredata.dc:description: Lithium-sulfur batteries suffer from poor cycling stability because of the intrinsic shuttling effect of intermediate polysulfides and sluggish reaction kinetics, especially at high rates and high sulfur loading. Herein, we report the construction of a CoP-Co2N@N-doped carbon polyhedron uniformly anchored on three-dimensional carbon nanotubes/graphene (CoP-Co2N@NC/CG) scaffold as a sulfur reservoir to achieve the trapping-diffusion-conversion of polysulfides. Highly active CoP-Co2N shows marvelous catalytic effects by effectively accelerating the reduction of sulfur and the oxidation of Li2S during the discharging and charging process, respectively, while the conductive NC/CG network with massive mesoporous channels ensures fast and continuous long-distance electron/ion transportation. DFT calculations demonstrate that the CoP-Co2N with excellent intrinsic conductivity serves as job-synergistic immobilizing-conversion sites for polysulfides through the formation of P···Li/N···Li and Co···S bonds. As a result, the S@CoP-Co2N@NC/CG cathode (sulfur content 1.7 mg cm−2) exhibits a high capacity of 988 mAh g−1 at 2 C after 500 cycles, which is superior to most of the electrochemical performance reported. Even under high sulfur content (4.3 mg cm−2), it also shows excellent cyclability with high capacity at 1 C.

coredata.dc:title: Highly active CoP-Co2N confined in nanocarbon enabling efficient electrocatalytic immobilizing-conversion of polysulfide targeting high-rate lithium-sulfur batteries
